summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida today entered a final judgment in favor of the Baldwins' motion for summary judgment against the defendants.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Tampa, Florida, alleges that the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the complaint, the defendants were not entitled to a homestead exemption for their residential property for tax year 2015 because they did not maintain the subject property as their permanent residence until six months into the year for which they were claiming the exemption.  In addition, the complaint alleges that, because they were unable to physically occupy the property as of January 1, 2015, they were entitled to an exemption from property taxes until the construction of a new house was completed in June 2015.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's Complaint, the Defendants consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins them from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, orders them to pay a civil penalty of $25,000, and bars them from serving as officers or directors of any Florida-based public agency. The judgment also prohibits the defendants from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the issuance of any security or exemption, and orders the defendants to pay disgorgement of their ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, a civil monetary penalty, and a penny stock bar. The defendants also agreed to be permanently enjoined from associating with any third party that may be associated with a third party in violation of the same federal securities law. The court's order also prohibits them from imposing any monetary penalty against any third-party, including the defendants' spouses.  On the same day, the court granted the defendants a temporary restraining order and issued an order requiring them to return to their prior residences. The order also requires the defendants not to violate the federal registration provisions of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ("Advisers Act").  The court also ordered the property appraiser to conduct an examination to determine whether the property is worth acquiring and whether it qualifies as a "permanent residence."  In a parallel action, the Florida Secretary of State's Office today announced that it had obtained an order appointing a receiver to oversee the acquisition, construction, and operation of the property. The receiver has agreed to the appointment of a receiver and to the payment of a penalty equal to the amount of his or her disgorg
